facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1430 and 1431 of 1974 were filed by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd November 1973 of the Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. Nos. 423 and 430 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION.-Civil Appeal Nos. 1430 and 1431 of 1974. From the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd November, 1973 of the Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. Nos. 423 and 430 of 1973.

facts.text: Three candidates competed for two posts of Lecturer in Orthopaedics in government medical colleges in Patna and Darbhanga in Bihar: Dr. Mukherjee, Dr. Ram, and Dr. Jamuar.

anchor.surface_text: The two appeals before us, by special leave, unfold a musical-chair type situation where three candidates ran for two posts in the government-run Patna and Dharbanga Medical Colleges.

facts.text: Dr. Mukherjee was screened as ineligible despite his British work and experience.

anchor.surface_text: Inevitably one lost or, rather, was screened as ineligible, his British work and experience numberwithstanding,

facts.text: Dr. Mukherjee challenged the selection by writ petition claiming he was qualified and superior due to his British career compared to Dr. Ram and Dr. Jamuar.

anchor.surface_text: and, chagrined by his discomfiture, he Dr. Mukherjee, challenged the whole selection by a writ petition on the short and ambitious ground that he was number only qualified but superior, with his bright British career, to the other two India-trained hands, Dr. Ram and Dr. Jamuar,

facts.text: Patna High Court allowed the writ petition, probed Cabinet papers, upset government orders of appointment, upheld petitioner's eligibility, and directed reconsideration of claims.

anchor.surface_text: The main issue what arises and was argued before us by he States companynsel, supported by Shri Garg for the other candidates, is that the High Court, which allowed the writ petition, grievously erred in probing improperly into the companycerned Cabinet. papers and upsetting governments orders of appointment, upholding the petitioners eligibility and directing a reconsideration of the claims of all the companytenders

facts.text: The central dispute is whether Dr. Mukherjee possessed the prescribed qualifications, specifically teaching experience for at least three years in orthopaedics or allied subjects in a teaching institution.

anchor.surface_text: Certain peripheral companytentions apart, the companye of the matter is the possession by Dr. Mukherjee of teaching experience as Regiscrar for at least three years in orthopaedics or allied subjects in a teaching institution.

facts.text: Dr. Mukherjee worked for three years as Registrar under British orthopaedic surgeons.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie he has worked for three years under apparently outstanding British orthopaedic surgeons.

facts.text: Dr. Mukherjee filed C.W.J.C. 754 of 1972 contending he acquired required teaching experience in the United Kingdom.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bihar took the view, while appointing lecturers in Orthopaedics, that the first respondent did number have the necessary teaching experience in a teaching institution whereupon he sought refuse in the writ jurisdiction of the High Court and filed C.W.J.C. 754 of 1972 companytending that he had acquired the required teaching experience during the time he worked in the United Kingdom

facts.text: A circular letter issued by the Deputy Director of Health Services dated April 14, 1963 was cited by the State.

anchor.surface_text: A circular letter issued by the Deputy Director of Health Services, dated April 14, 1963 was also cited

facts.text: High Court in first writ directed Government to reconsider Dr. Mukherjee's case along with others; Government did so but held against his eligibility.

anchor.surface_text: The Court, however, quashed the decision of Government and directed it to reconsider the case of the 1st respondent here together with this of the other two. Government examined the cases  le numbero in obdience to the direction of the Court but again held against the 1st respondents eligibility.

facts.text: Dr. Mukherjee filed second writ and succeeded; High Court quashed order and directed State to consider his claim, finding he possessed requisite experience.

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved 1st respondent hurried to the High Court again and succeeded a second time in persuading it to quash the order and to issue a writ to the State to. companysider the claim of Dr. Mukherjee, the 1st respondent, finding that be did possess the requisite experience.

facts.text: High Court examined Cabinet papers and reports of officers.

anchor.surface_text: In so doing the High Court called for and examined the Cabinet papers and other reports and numberings of the officers, technical and administrative.

facts.text: State claims teaching experience must be in India, not abroad.

anchor.surface_text: That the teaching experience in teaching institutions visualised by the regulations must be in India and number abroad.

facts.text: Dr. Mukherjee's post of Registrar in England did not carry teaching functions according to State.

anchor.surface_text: The post of Registrar filled by Dr. Mukherjee in England had number been shown to carry among its functions teaching,

facts.text: Hospitals where Dr. Mukherjee worked were not proved to be teaching institutions recognized by MCI or under British Act.

anchor.surface_text: In any view, the hospitals, the the Universities to which they were linked, where Dr. Mukherjee worked were number proved to be teaching institutions either recognised by the Medical Council of India or regarded as such under the provisions of the British National Health Service Act.

facts.text: Some testimonials of Dr. Mukherjee were not reliable without further proof.

anchor.surface_text: The testimonials produced by the 1st respondent or at least some of them were number reliable and companyld number, without-further proof, be treated as probative of their companytents.

facts.text: Government of Bihar adopted the circular of April 14, 1963 on July 13, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court  vide para 24 of its judgment  that the said circular though adopted by Governm-nt on July 13. 1972

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that teaching institutions abroad recognized under ss.12,13,14 of MCI Act qualify.

anchor.surface_text: Teaching institutions abroad number being ruled out, we companysider it right to reckon as companypetent and qualitatively acceptable those institutions which are linked with, or are recognised as teaching institutions by the Universities and organisations in Schedule 11 and Schedule III and recognised by the Central Government under s. 14.

facts.text: Dr. Mukherjee produced certificates from professors like Dr. Robert Roaf and Dr. Geoffrey Osborne stating he participated in teaching.

anchor.surface_text: He did, if we read his certificates issued by professors like Dr. Robert Roaf and Dr. Geoffrey Osbrone.

facts.text: Supreme Court remands to Government to reconsider eligibility of Dr. Mukherjee and relative merits of all candidates by February 15, 1975, allowing evidence till end of January 1975.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondents eligibility on the basis of the relevant regulation will be examined afresh before February 15, 1975, the parties, particularly the 1st respondent,, being at liberty to adduce materials to satisfy the State Government on his qualifications  or otherwise  on or before the last day of January, 1975.

facts.text: Appointments of Dr. Ram and Dr. Jamuar declared bad in law.

anchor.surface_text: We declare the orders of appointment of the appellants in A. No. 1431 of 1974 as bad in law

facts.text: State of Bihar is appellant in CA 1430/1974 with Health Commissioner and Health Minister.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner before the High Court. Dr. Mukherjee, is the 1st respondent in both the atppeals before us while the State of Bihar, the Health Commissioner and the Health Minister are the atppellants in C.A. 1430 of 1974.

facts.text: Dr. Ram and Dr. Jamuar are appellants in CA 1431/1974.

anchor.surface_text: The defeated doctors Dr. Ram and Dr. Jamuar, whose appointments have been upset by the High Court, are the appellants in the companynected appeal No. 1431 of 1974.

facts.text: Case argued for three days in Supreme Court based on three volumes of records.

anchor.surface_text: The case has taken three days of argument based on three heavy volumes of appeal records-mercifully less than the eight days of hearing in the High Court.

facts.text: High Court judgment spanned 59 pages.

anchor.surface_text: but too abstruse, when examined in the forensic crucible, to be disposed of in less than 59 pages by the High Court

issues.text: Did the petitioner possess the prescribed qualifications for the post?

anchor.surface_text: Did the petitioner possess the prescribed qualifications for the post ? If he did, the High Court was right in directing the appointing authority to consider his claims and if did not Government rightly ignored his credentials for the post as an unqualified hand, despite his impressive British testimonials and good showing 8 97 otherwise.

issues.text: What is the precise construction of the blurred expression 'teaching experience in a teaching institution' occurring in the regulations framed by the Medical Council of India under s. 33 of the Indian Medical Council Act, 1956?

anchor.surface_text: Art. 226 of the Constitution has come to be a universe numbspectrum but judicial robes are not omniscient. The whole case turns on the precise construction of the blurred expression teaching experience in a teaching institution occurring in the regulations

issues.answer: yes (interpreted to include qualifying foreign experience in recognized institutions)

issues.text: Whether the teaching experience in teaching institutions visualised by the regulations must be in India and not abroad.

anchor.surface_text: That the teaching experience in teaching institutions visualised by the regulations must be in India and not abroad. If this be valid, the 1st respondent would be clean bowled, since his qualifications in this regard were attained in England.

issues.text: Whether the post of Registrar filled by Dr. Mukherjee in England had been shown to carry among its functions teaching, so that the length of occupancy of that office did not prove teaching experience even assuming that British Medical Institutions could come within the purview of the regulations.

anchor.surface_text: The post of Registrar filled by Dr. Mukherjee in England had not been shown to carry among its functions teaching, so that the length of occupancy of that office did not prove teaching experience even assuming that British Medical Institutions could come within the purview of the regulations.

issues.text: Whether the hospitals, the Universities to which they were linked, where Dr. Mukherjee worked were proved to be teaching institutions either recognised by the Medical Council of India or regarded as such under the provisions of the British National Health Service Act.

anchor.surface_text: In any view, the hospitals, the the Universities to which they were linked, where Dr. Mukherjee worked were not proved to be teaching institutions either recognised by the Medical Council of India or regarded as such under the provisions of the British National Health Service Act.

issues.text: Whether the testimonials produced by the 1st respondent or at least some of them were reliable and could, without further proof, be treated as probative of their contents.

anchor.surface_text: The testimonials produced by the 1st respondent or at least some of them were not reliable and could not, without-further proof, be treated as probative of their contents.

issues.text: Whether the High Court should have called for and examined the Cabinet papers and other reports and numberings of the officers, technical and administrative.

issues.text: Whether appointments to posts need be accompanied by speaking orders or reasoned grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, appointments to posts need not be accompanied by speaking orders or reasoned grounds. Then the wheels of Government will slow down to a grinding halt, tardy as it is even otherwise.

issues.text: Whether there is an obligation to consider every qualified candidate implicit in Arts. 14 and 16, and whether screening out an eligible candidate is illegal.

anchor.surface_text: implicit in the equal opportunity right enshrined in Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution. Screening a candidate out of consideration altogether is illegal if the applicant has eligibility under the regulations.

holdings.text: Teaching institutions abroad are not ruled out; competent foreign institutions are those linked with or recognised by universities/organisations in Schedule II and III or by Central Government under s.14 of IMC Act.

anchor.surface_text: Teaching institutions abroad not being ruled out, we consider it right to reckon as competent and qualitatively acceptable those institutions which are linked with, or are recognised as teaching institutions by the Universities and organisations in Schedule II and Schedule III and recognised by the Central Government under s. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of IMC Act provisions recognizing foreign qualifications (ss.11-14, Schedules); rejects India-only limit as untenable given statutory scheme promoting high standards.

holdings.text: Appointments to posts need not be accompanied by speaking orders or reasoned grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, appointments to posts need not be accompanied by speaking orders or reasoned grounds. Then the wheels of Government will slow down to a grinding halt, tardy as it is even otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy consideration: requiring reasons would paralyze government functioning; relevant reasons must still animate but no formal order needed.

holdings.text: Obligation to consider every qualified candidate implicit in Arts.14 and 16; screening out eligible candidate altogether illegal.

anchor.surface_text: implicit in the equal opportunity right enshrined in Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution. Screening a candidate out of consideration altogether is illegal if the applicant has eligibility under the regulations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional equality mandates consideration of all eligible; exclusion without manifest grounds violates regulations and rights.

holdings.text: Court has power under certiorari to call records but sensitive government materials not to be routinely sent without mala fides or special circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: When a writ of certiorari is moved, the Court has the power to call for the record, but in case where mala fides is not alleged or other special circumstances set out, sensitive materials in the possession of government may not routinely be sent for.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial restraint in review; power wide but exercised judiciously considering totality and avoiding routine prying into cabinet papers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Natural meaning; marginal doubt but technical issue for executive verification, not hair-splitting.

precedents.citation: Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher

anchor.surface_text: as Denning, L.J., in Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher , observed When a defect appears a Judge cannot simply fold his hands and blame the draftsman. He must set to work on the company

precedents.case_name: Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher
precedents.cited_proposition: When a defect appears in a statute, a judge cannot simply fold his hands and blame the draftsman but must find the intention of Parliament, supplement the written words to give force and life to the intention, and iron out the creases without altering the material of the Act.
precedents.cited_holding: A judge must set to work on the constructive task of finding the intention of Parliament and then he must supplement the written words so as to give force and life to the intention of legislature... He can and should iron out the creases.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Teaching Experience in Teaching Institution (MCI Regulations) support

anchor.surface_text: With these observations, we dismiss the appeals with costs against the State only, and only in favour of Respondent Dr. Mukherjee.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed. Orders of appointment of Dr. Ram and Dr. Jamuar declared bad in law. State Government directed to reconsider de novo claims of all candidates including Dr. Mukherjee for the two lecturer posts, with liberty to produce additional evidence by Jan 31, 1975 and decide by Feb 15, 1975.
directions: Orders of appointment of the appellants in C.A. No. 1431 of 1974 declared bad in law
Appellants in C.A. No. 1430 of 1974 (State) directed to reconsider de novo the appointments to the two posts of lecturers in conformity with the findings and observations made above
First respondent's (Dr. Mukherjee) eligibility to be examined afresh before February 15, 1975
Parties, particularly 1st respondent, at liberty to adduce materials by end of January, 1975
Government free to consult technical authorities before decision
No obligation to make speaking order
Duty of Government not to delay fresh appointments after receipt of materials
